newsitem.title: INDIA: Doctors struggle to save victims of India inferno.
newsitem.headline: Doctors struggle to save victims of India inferno.

text.p: Doctors struggled on Monday to save dozens of badly burned victims of a raging blaze that engulfed a gathering of Hindu worshippers in eastern India, killing at least 182 people, authorities said.
"At the moment more than 100 doctors are working on the patients," Dr Binoy Kumar Aggarwal of District Headquarters Hospital in Baripada town told Reuters.

Blackened bodies lay strewn across the makeshift camp site where 158 devotees were burnt alive on Sunday when flames tore through a cluster of makeshift bamboo and straw shelters, packed with napping worshippers.
"It looks like a burial ground with dead bodies littered all over," said P.K. Mishra, deputy police chief of Baripada town where the inferno struck on Sunday.
The inferno erupted on the last day of a convention dedicated to a Hindu guru in Baripada, about 220 km (135 miles) north of the capital of Orissa state, Bhubaneshwar.
Aggarwal said 24 of 187 injured died in hospital. About a dozen others were in serious condition in the Baripada hospital with burns to over 70 to 80 percent of their bodies.

Another 24 patients in very serious condition had been shifted to a hospital in Cuttack, about 175 km (110 miles) southwest of Baripada, Aggarwal said. At least 50 doctors had rushed to Baripada headquarters hospital to complement the resident team of a similar number.

The inferno swept through the temporary huts on the last day of a convention dedicated to a Hindu guru. All the victims were believed to be male. The cause of the fire was thought to be a short circuit or gas cylinder that exploded.
"The scene looked like people were roasted alive on a battlefield," said resident Amarendra. "The bodies were so mutilated that they were beyond recognition."

"I saw rows of charred bodies," said Sandeep Sahu, a local journalist who arrived at the site early on Monday, more than 14 hours after the fire erupted. "The structures were razed to the ground and I could still smell the smoke."

Sahu said about one third of the 158 bodies had been marked with identification tags, but others were disfigured. "Relatives were crying desperately, looking for any information from police," he said.
The Orissa home (interior) secretary, S.C. Hota, said strong winds fanned the fire, which broke out at about 3:30 p.m. (1000 GMT) on Sunday.
The flames swiftly engulfed eight huts in the camp at Baripada, 175 km (110 miles) southwest of Calcutta, he said.

Most of the victims were men taking a siesta after lunch at the annual national convention, dedicated to the memory of the Hindu guru Nigamananda, Hota said. "The number of exits at the camp was very limited," Hota said. "That was a problem."
Women and children attending the convention which began last Thursday were in 10 huts in a separate area of the camp.
Straw had been spread on the ground to serve as bedding. The temperature in the region was 32 degrees Celsius (90 Fahrenheit) and the weather was dry.
"Accommodation for the delegates was made almost entirely of straw," survivor Bhagbal Sahu said. "That made it easier for the fire to spread and hardly allowed people any time to get out."
